docs.lead_paragraph: Blood vessel disease has been added as a cause of low-back problems, joining the ranks of improper lifting techniques and overly soft mattresses. Researchers have found evidence that blockages from factors that include smoking, high blood pressure and high cholesterol may be factors in back pain and lumbar degenerative disease.

headline.main: Clogged Vessels Linked to Aching Backs

docs.abstract: Researchers find that blood vessel disease, such as clogged vessels, are factor in low-back problems (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hallucinogenic drugs like LSD and peyote -- derided as toys of the hippie generation -- are increasingly drawing the interest of neurologists and psychiatrists who want to test the idea that they may be valuable tools in treating a range of mental disorders. Although there are anecdotal reports that psychedelic drugs can help some people with mental illness, the idea has never been substantiated by mainstream psychiatry and remains highly controversial -- some would say outlandish.

headline.main: Scientists Test Hallucinogens For Mental Ills

docs.lead_paragraph: A longer life is a better life. Or so common wisdom assumes. But is a longer life that is filled with modest pleasure and accomplishment better than a shorter life of intense happiness and success? Not necessarily, according to research by a social psychologist at the University of Illinois, Dr. Edward Diener. In a series of studies, Dr. Diener and colleagues found that when people were asked to judge the desirability of a life, they gave far more weight to how the life ended than to its duration.

headline.main: Rating Life: Live Fast, Die Young

docs.lead_paragraph: ''A Piece of My Mind,'' edited by Roxanne K. Young, AMA Press, $34. There is an especially touching moment in this collection of essays from The Journal of the American Medical Association that reveals how a simple common interest, an instance of shared humanity, can strengthen an otherwise tense relationship between a physician and a patient.

docs.lead_paragraph: In what amounts to a warning to women under 60 who have had heart attacks, a new study finds that they are significantly more likely to die in the two years after the heart attacks than are men. The study, published in a recent issue of The Annals of Internal Medicine, suggests that those patients need to be especially aggressive about getting good follow-up care, the authors said.

headline.main: A Warning for Women With Bad Hearts

How can you be certain that the pathologist reading your biopsy slides is qualified to make the diagnosis?

docs.lead_paragraph: We all grew up knowing that carrots are good for our eyes. Carrots, among other deeply colored vegetables and fruits, are rich sources of beta carotene, the plant-based building block for vitamin A, which is required to form the visual pigment rhodopsin that allows people to see in the dark. One eventual consequence of a chronic vitamin A deficiency is night blindness, which remains a scourge among children in many poor countries and sometimes among poorly nourished children in this country.

headline.main: Unveiling a New Arsenal for Eye Health

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on influence of diet on vision; discusses nutrients that are important for eye health and their sources (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Albert Hoffman, the Swiss chemist who discovered LSD in 1943 and was the first person known to have taken an acid trip, described his experience as having two parts: ''On the way home, my condition began to assume threatening forms,'' he wrote in his journal. ''My surroundings had now transformed themselves in more terrifying ways. Everything in the room spun around, and the familiar objects and pieces of furniture assumed grotesque, threatening forms.'' But after a while, ''the horror softened and gave way to a feeling of good fortune and gratitude.''

headline.main: This Is the Brain On Hallucinogens

docs.abstract: Scientists discuss effects of hallucinogens on architecture of brain (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past 50 years, the death rate from heart disease has gone down over all in the United States. But, surprisingly, among young people it has gone up. Federal health officials, reporting at a recent conference of the American Heart Association, said they had found an increase in the rate of sudden cardiac death among 15- to 34-year-olds.

headline.main: Heart Disease Rises in Young People

docs.abstract: Federal health officials report that heart disease among young people has gone up, even though death rate from heart disease has gone down all across America over last 50 years (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of people take over-the-counter doses of vitamin E every day in the belief that they may help them avoid diseases like Alzheimer's, cancer and hardening of the arteries. But a new study suggests that the best that can be said about the supplement is that it does no harm, although some other studies suggest possible eye benefits.

headline.main: Little Value Found in Added Vitamin E

docs.abstract: Study finds evidence that vitamin E supplements may offer eye benefit, but no evidence that they are useful as antioxidants; the best that can be said about them is that they do no harm (S)
